country:
None
text:
Two of us who are public school teachers had the day off so we got together and each made one batch of the "classic peanut butter cookies."  We made the recipe exactly as written except she used fresh ground organic peanut butter from the grocery store and I opened up and jar of creamy Jif, a well known brand with a strong flavor.  We each stirred in one cup of chocolate chips.   We both made our cookies the same size and used parchment paper as a liner on the cookie sheets.  
Hers turned out more flaky and lighter in texture, color and taste.  Mine were more dense, more chewy, slightly more carmel colored and flavorful.  Took 'em to a party and people went crazy for them!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great!
I made these with regular salted butter, and creamy peanut butter. I didn't refrigerated dough at all.
I simply scooped them with a mini ice cream scoop, and that made the perfect round shape and size.
When making fork patterns onto the unchilled dough, I dip the fork into granulated sugar before each press. Then it won't stick and you can just skip the whole refrigerating step.
I also sprinkle more granulated sugar over cookie tops before I bake.
Absolutely classic and deeeeeelish!!
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
This recipe is great! It doesn't take long to mix or to bake, only when it says put dough in refrigerator for an hour they aren't kidding. The first time I tried making them I baked the cookies without refrigerating the dough and they didn't turn out well. The next time I refrigerated the dough for an hour and they came out perfect. In baking just as it is in life, when all else fails follow the instructions :-).

text:
Easy-peasy recipe to make and these cookies are delicious. I followed the recipe and took into consideration the comments/reviews here regarding "flat cookies".  I had that same problem over Christmas with my oatmeal raisin cookie recipe...By reducing the white sugar by 1/4 cup and added 1/2 cup more flour made this recipe come out just right.  Cooking time in my oven ranged about 12 -14 minutes. I tested a few before baking an entire batch and that seemed about right for this recipe.

text:
Needs 2tsp Vanilla Extract.

recommend weighing out 6 - 1oz balls, flattening out, and cooking  at 10 mins; then adjusting weight/flatten amount  to get the perfect consistency.  e.g.: I can do 10 1oz balls or 20 .5 oz balls with the same "push downness" and they have the perfect center after 10mins.  if I do 1.1oz or .6oz at 10mins with the same smushness it's too gooey, and .9 or .4 oz it's too hard. (I don't know why, but that fork hatch pattern is quintessential peanutbutter cookie...  I made peanut butter cookies without that hatch and with sprinkles... just not the same... wouldn't recommend...)

text:
This is an AMAZING recipe. I took others advice and added 1/2 cup more flour and 1/2 cup more peanut butter. I also added a splash of vanilla, some ginger and peanut butter chips. Refrigerated dough for an hour. Cooked at 315 because my first batch I baked at 350 and the bottoms turned brown way too quickly as the rest of the cookie was still undone. Usually with half of the dough I will make into balls, flatten a bit and dip the top in turbinado sugar.. Then about half way through baking add a spoon full of strawberry preserves to the top. The other half I pull out halfway, do the cross with the fork and top with Reese's pieces or 
chopped up Reese's peanut butter cups. I usually refrigerate the candies while the first half of the baking is done. These cookies turn out perfectly every time now and stay soft and fluffy for days. So glad I tried this one again, absolutely a keeper.

userID:
24705884
Display Name:
KitchenGardener
isPro:

favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never given a review before, but I saw how many people had problems with thin cookies and no one explained why. The difference is the peanut butter. Check the ingredients: if it mentions oil, particularly 'fully hydrogenated vegetable oil', the cookie dough will soften in the oven and the cookies will be flat. Hydrogenated vegetable oil is solid at room temp, but liquid when you warm it up in the oven. It doesn't matter if you refrigerate it for an hour or a week, it will still get warm in the oven and melt. If you use a peanut butter that only has peanuts, and maybe sugar and salt, you must flatten the cookies with a fork, because they won't flatten on their own. If you can't get peanut butter without added oil, you have to reduce the amount of butter, but the flavor won't be as good.  Also, if you use good peanut butter, you can pour off the excess peanut oil from the top first. Then you can increase the peanut butter by as much as double. The cookies will be more crumbly, but they won't flatten and they will have more peanut flavor. The only other 'tweak' I would suggest is a teaspoon of vanilla. BTW, it is hard to tell from the label if the peanut butter has a little added oil or a lot, but if it is more than 190 calories per 2Tbls, it has too much added oil or too much sugar. And, if it says 'molasses', it has so much added oil it would be white if they didn't add something to make it brown.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-08T06:48:52.853
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Needed to make 4 dozen cookies for a Christmas party, and who doesnt like a peanut butter cookie? I took the advice of others and upped the flour and peanut butter to help with spreading. I doubled the batch according to the recipe and added 3/4 cup of flour and 1 cup of peanut butter. Used a pretty decent sized ice cream scoop, I think a 3 tbs one, and baked for 7.5 minutes in my convection oven, flipping the pan about halfway through. They were perfect! I dipped them in chocolate and decorated with a few sprinkles. People thought they were from a bakery and a few have asked to buy some for their other parties this season. This is a great recipe!
Review:
Rating:
3

None
text:
This is a perfect old-fashioned cookie recipe. I added 1/4c more flour and a smidge more peanut butter. I use a small ice cream scoop to scoop the cookies. I also spray my fork with a bit of canola oil to keep it from sticking. Parchment paper keeps the cookies uniform, and the sheet clean. Let the cookie sit in the cookie sheet for 2 minutes before removing to a cooling rack. A favorite of my college-aged daughter and her floor mates!

text:
Very good, chewy soft , I like that but be sure to let them sit for about 10 min before scraping up or they can break,  also if you make them small and taller then flat before you bake them you will not have an issue with them flattening out and cool dough helps too not room temp. I cooked mine just a few min more too to be sure no breaking up and added some nuts and vanilla. I will be using this recipe again for new years cookies.

text:
These had a great consistency, no problems with being thin at all, and I only refrigerated for 30 minutes! Not sure why some had issues with that. I flattened and made the criss cross too! However, they didn't have a lot of peanut butter flavor. Next time I'll add vanilla extract and more peanut butter. They tasted better after being in the cookie jar all night, though! My Mom loved them as is!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This may possibly be the best peanut butter cookie I have ever made. The dough was a little loose, so, I added  an extra 1/4 cup flour to it, I only added 1/2 cup demerara sugar instead of 1 cup of white sugar , and only used 2/3 cup packed brown sugar, and the cookie was just right in sweetness. Thanks Shirley for the recipe. I did not flatten them much at all and make marks. I rather rolled the dough before baking in sugar, and just pushed it down a very little  with my hand and they baked up beautifully into a lovely crinkle cookie. My husband was bonkers for them.

text:
I added 1/4 cup extra flour, a teaspoon of vanilla and an extra 1/2 cup of peanut butter.   I also added a half a bag of toffee pieces.   I used a cookie scoop and dipped the top of the cookie in sugar and pressed them down with a spatula.   I don't know the size of my scoop, but  smaller than a golf ball.   I baked them for 11 minutes and the outside was crispy and the inside chewy.   BEST PEANUT BUTTER COOKIE I EVER MADE!   Big hit at home, big hit at the office the next day and the recipe made about 3 dozen.   This will forever be my go-to peanut butter cookie recipe.

text:
Great taste! Took some people's suggestions and made the following edits:
- added 1/4 c peanut butter
- added 1/2 c flour
- added 1 tsp vanilla extract
- sprinkled caster sugar on each cookie before baking

As for cooking time: I would set the timer for 10 minutes, then check every minute or so until the dough juuuust cracked. Result: chewy cookies!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies came out AHmazing! My pregnant wife was soooo happy. I added an extra 1/4 c of flour and an extra couple spoonfulls of peanut butter, in addition to 1 tbs of vanilla extract. I let the butter sticks sit out to get nice and soft then whipped it on high speed with the sugar. Once it was whipped I added the peanut butter and vanilla extract and whipped again on high speed. I set the mixer to low and slowly added the dry ingredients and mixed until just barely combined. I let it set in the fridge for 2 hours then made 1 oz balls, rolled in my hands then dipped in sugar on one side which I then scored with a fork. I baked at 350 for 12 minutes. They came out nice and crisp on the outside with a moist chewy center. WIll def be saving this one!

text:
I made these last night and they turned out pretty good. I used whole wheat flour instead of white, and instead of regular crunchy peanut butter, I used a creamy natural maple honey peanut butter (it has the maple and honey already mixed in). They are delicious and satisfying. 

I found that the dough spread quite a bit when baked, so pay attention to the 1-inch sizing directions. I also started baking them with the crisscross pattern, but after the first batch, the dough started to warm up and I had to peel the cookie from the fork after pressing it. I stopped bothering, and I actually like the crackled look they get better than the crisscross. 

I might make these again for the holidays with red and green food coloring and a few autumnal spices like cinnamon, nutmeg, etc.

text:
You know the recipe for that thing you cook or bake that everyone swoons over and always asks you to make for special occasions or get-togethers? Thats your holy grail recipe. And that dish is as closely associated with you as is your signature fragrance, or your spirit animal, or your favorite team (this is how people know what to buy you at holidays). The Classic Peanut Butter Cookie recipe is my first HG recipe not handed down to me by someone else, which is a sign of killing it at #midlifeing (which is adulting for the 35+ set). I did add vanilla, as others have mentioned. I also love the flavor and texture Creamy Jif and raw sugar give to this cookie, so I make those swaps. Its definitely a sweet cookie, so you may prefer to cut down some of the sugar and adjust your other ingredients accordingly, which I experiment with a bit depending on if Im making peanut butter blossoms (rolled in green sugar at Christmas) or adding chocolate chips (sometime semi-sweet, sometimes half semi-sweet and half milk chocolate). My friends and family rave about these cookies. I make small batches for myself and freeze them but they still dont stick around as long as they should. Baking is literally a science and to be successful you have to be precise. For baked goods recipes, I tend to take negative reviews with a grain of salt because there are many variables that contribute to successful vs unsuccessful outcomes. I learned a lot from my mom and old episodes of Martha Bakes, but I sti

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
They were good.  They were sweet.  A couple of things you really need to know if you make cookies.  You don't have to sift the dry ingredients together...at all.  Just cream butters and sugars and put the salt, baking powder, and baking soda in.  Mix for another 30 seconds and then add the eggs and cream it for another minute.  Add the flour and mix.  believe me, the dry ingredients WILL incorporate evenly.  I don't know why people try to make things more difficult than they should be.  Also, there is no reason to make "hash marks" on these cookies unless you want to make them look like old fashioned peanut butter cookies.  The original  reason for the marks  was because very little butter was used and we had to push them down a bit for them to spread out enough.  This batter is very loose and trying to get the fork not to pick up the batter between the tines is a pain.  Just sayin', trying to make an easy recipe hard is silly.  The cookie is a little too sweet for my taste and not enough peanut butter flavor, but my family loved them.  I'll make them again.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2018-07-05T21:55:49.02

Followed the recipe to a T. Oven temperature and cook times were the same. They burned. 

Second half of the batch that went in the oven went in at 325. They still burned but just a little cause I kept an eye on them. Definitely a recipe problem. I would halve the amount of brown sugar in these and halve the butter, as well as cool at 325 for 6-8 minutes instead of 375 for 10. Bad recipe.

text:
These cookies were delicious. I took recommendations of some reviewers: I also added an extra 1/2 cup peanut butter, 1/4 cup extra flour and 1ts. vanilla. I cooked them at 350 degrees for 11 minutes and cooled on tray for 2 minutes. I lined my pans with parchment paper.  I got about 3 dozen cookies since we like big cookies.  These came out lightly crispy edges and a nice soft chewy center. I also sprinkled sugar over the tops after I used a fork in a crisscross pattern. These are now my go to peanut butter recipe.

text:
these cookies are GOOD, however, you should definitely add 1/2 cup more peanut butter, and 1/2 more flour. It'll make the cookies less flat, and just better all around. Let the dough chill in fridge to hold fat, therefore making the cookies tall and not flat. Some people like to press peanut butter cookies with a fork, and you can do that, however it makes them flat and I prefer them to be tall and gooey.

text:
These cookies are great and easy to make. I made a half batch since I only had 1/2 cup creamy peanut butter on hand. I also added chopped peanuts and some peanut butter baking chips. The Hubs loved them. Next time I may chop the baking chips before adding them so the flavor is throughout the whole cookie.  I did not refrigerate my dough. I changed my oven temp to 350 degrees and baked them for about 12 to 15 minutes. I used a 2 tablespoon scoop and only made a slight indentation with a fork. The cookies turned out great and didnt spread very much.   Thanks for sharing.

userID:
14222422
Display Name:
Sherry
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This excellent, yummy recipe makes roughly 3 dozen cookies. I followed the ingredients almost exactly with a few alterations to avoid the unnecessary hour wait in the fridge - nobody has time for that these days, lol! Instead of using 2 1/2 cups of flour, I used an even 3 cups. This helps thicken the dough without waiting. Also, to avoid flattened cookies as some reviewers complained about, I dissolved the baking soda in 1 tbs of hot water which creates a nice thick texture to the cookie with crispy edges and chewy middle (a good cookie recipes secret weapon) - no refrigeration required! Beat 1 egg at a time. No need to sift the flour etc. Some reviewer complained the fork marks disappeared, mine were very visible using my method. For added flavour I added a capful of Mexican Vanilla and 3/4 cups of semi sweet chocolate chips! Double YUM! I gave a dozen to my brother who popped in while I was making them and he said, these are so  good, can I take some home? Haha! I should also add, the kids were in heaven when they came home from school to an amazing smell and deliciousness! Thank you for this delicious recipe! Id give it more stars if I could!  :)

text:
Im not the worlds best baker. So I try for the easy recipes and read the reviews for tips. I wouldnt even know what to change if I didnt read the reviews. I used salted butter, creamy PB, and added 1 tsp of vanilla. I cooked them on 350 for 10 min (my oven is old so keep that in mind). They turned out great! I kept the dough in fridge for an hour but kept putting it back in there when I was done with each batch. Never made them so someone said they had issues and said it wasnt in the fridge long enough. I rolled them in sugar and didnt fork them down flat. Just did the crisscross with the fork lightly. It flattened on its own.  Theyre delicious so far!

Followed the recipe exactly except I didn't press the cookies down at the end with a fork and they were a little shorter (chubbier and not as crispy) as I would have liked. Also think I used a fresh ground peanut butter which didn't have any salt so the cookies did not have the wonderful peanut taste of a roasted peanut butter cookie. The only reason I give 4 stars is because the recipe uses more sugar and butter than other recipes and the cookie did not blow my socks off but very solid. Enjoy!

Display Name:
Kelli K
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these cookies exactly as the recipe called for with one change and everyone loved them. 

Baking at 375F caused the bottom of the cookies to burn before the center was done. This may not be the case if you use foil to line the cookie sheet (the only reason I can think of for the foil tip), but the recipe didn't explicitly state it was necessary for proper baking so I didn't. I lowered the temperature to 350F for 12 minutes. The cookies definitely don't look ready  when they are ready to come out; however, if you take a bite and they don't taste doughy then they're done.

Some additional things I did that the recipe instructions didn't call for, with reasonings provided:

1.  Make sure the butter is at room temperature (not fully melted, just soft enough to be squishy).

2. Make sure the eggs are at room temperature. Mix them in one at a time and scrape the sides of the bowl with a spatula to make sure each egg is fully mixed in before adding the next.  They like to stick to the sides of the bowl!

3. I lined the bottom of the cookie sheet with parchment paper. Foil either attracts or repels heat based on if it's the shiny/matte side, but parchment paper doesn't interrupt the flow of heat and also keeps the cookies from sticking to the sheet.

 If you like a strong peanut butter taste, definitely add more peanut butter as some comments recommend.  If you're worried about the cookies going flat, refrigerate them longer than one hour; mine weren't pancakes but next time I
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-09-19T23:00:06.837

text:
I was getting confused with the changes people were making to the recipe and just wanted to try the recipe as it was written.  I followed directions explicitly.  To experiment, the first cookies I made were made with a melon baller on the small side, used a fork as stated in the directions to flatten them a little. These cookies seemed a little crumbly, so second try I made medium sized balls, these cookies were perfect.  The third try I made them bigger and they came a much bigger, thinner cookie which became harder the longer it sat.  I didn't have time to finish the whole batch so I froze what was left and baked them today using medium sized balls and they came out perfect.  So delicious.  Next time I think I will add a little more peanut butter because I like lots of nuts in them.  I didn't feel the need to add any more flour.  They were very tasty cookies according to my family and myself.  Love the recipe and glad I found the difference between making them too small and/or too big.  Thanks for the recipe.  And by the way, didn't miss vanilla at all.  PS took someone's advice and put the cookie dough back in the fridge between every batch.  This keeps the cookie dough very cold and easy to handle.

text:
The taste is really really good. BUT these will flatten out like little pancakes if you don't refrigerate longer. Put mine in the fridge, set the timer for an hour and laid them out. I followed the recipe exactly and they all ran together and spread out a TON! And I thought I made them small! Next pan I rolled even smaller and didn't even do the cross cross pattern. They turned out tasty but very thin. Even on a larger pan only put like 6 or 8 (if your doing them super small). The spreading of these little suckers will surprise you!  Also, I didn't have crunchy so I used smooth and I used about a teaspoon of vanilla, as I always throw a bit in almost everything when baking. Very good but I urge longer refrigeration! I've already had 3 and my husband had 7! Beast mode!

text:
This is a great recipe. I read some reviews about the cookies going flat. I have found when making cookies that beating the butter sugar and eggs until fluffy, then add the dry ingredients mixing only until incorporated, no longer! Keeps them from becoming flat. Over mixing dry ingredients can make tough cookies.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews and seeing all of the changes others made I decided to make them exactly as written only adding 1 teaspoon of vanilla and one cup of mini chocolate chips per preference.  Wanted to see if it needed improving before doing so.  The only thing I would do differently is maybe add another half cup of peanut butter. These were easy to make and I chilled the dough for about  3 hours. 
I baked them in a convection oven for 10 minutes.  I gently made my marks with a fork without pushing them down flat  
My cookies did not spread and flatten as others complained about .  I grate my cold butter and then mix it just enough to blend as I find if I overmix butter or let it get too soft the cookies tend to spread and flatten.  I would definitely make these again.  I got 40 cookies from one recipe as I am using them for a party, otherwise I would have made them much larger.  Unfortunately I only had smooth peanut better, but I would definitely buy chunky to make these again .
Thank you Shirley!  Your cookies were fine without all of the changes others suggested. There is another recipe posted  by Chef John which is exactly the same  ingredients,  just smaller amounts of ingredients that has rave reviews without all of the tips to change it.  I went with this one as I knew would make more cookies .

text:
What's so great about this recipe (besides being ultra-easy) is that I can make the dough, keep it in the fridge and make fresh baked cookies every day for a FEW days. We all know nothing's better than warm cookies right out'a the oven! Especially when there's a coooold glass 'o milk sittin' there waiting ...

These consistently come out crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. Perfect!!!

One addition I make: When I roll the dough into balls, I also roll them in sugar (yes, sugar!) then fork 'em.  Seriously, what's another gram of sugar? Maybe this is what makes them crunchy . . .

None
text:
These are easy and delicious. I used a hand mixer to mix peanut butter, softened butter, sugars and chunky peanut butter. Then one at a time I beat in eggs,  vanilla extract, baking powder and baking soda. Stirred in flour. Chilled for 30 mins. My only suggestion is not to press fork all the way into the cookie dough. bake 7 mins tops. baking longer will cause cookies to thin out and spread. Yummy!

text:
I made this recipe exactly as it is written, except that I halved it. Halved, it made 30 or so. I baked them for 9 minutes and left them on the cookie sheet for a minute or two before removing to the cooling rack. They taste delicious and are very soft if eaten soon after baking. They do get a little crisper with time but still have a good texture. This is exactly how I expect a peanut butter cookie to turn out. Certainly ovens and personal taste vary, but  in my opinion, this is a great classic cookie.

This is the best peanut butter cookie ever! I have been making this exact recipe for over 40 years. I do add 1 tsp. Vanilla. That is the Only change. text:
I've made these twice, and both family and friends loved them.  I rolled the dough balls in granulated sugar before placing them on the cookie sheet, for a little something extra.  If you don't mind taking a bit of extra time, that's nice.  I chilled them for longer than one hour - probably about 4 hours on one batch, and overnight on the other.  That may be why mine did not over-flatten like some of the negative reviewers' did.  Also be sure not to press them too flat with your fork, and don't over-bake.  I forgot to make the criss-cross on top, on a couple of trays, before baking.  The cookies still came out great -- but they will develop little cracks on top as they bake, if you forget to flatten with your fork in the criss-cross pattern before baking.  I'll probably try using more peanut butter and less butter next time, following some suggestions in the top-rated reviews.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-02-02T06:55:16.743
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
8181010
Display Name:
Matthew Acheson

text:
Really enjoyed this recipe close to "as is". I did not add extra flour or vanilla as other reviewers but I did eyeball the peanut butter and very well could have added at least an extr 1/4C. I chilled my dough overnight. The result was a well-balanced, flavorful cookie. The cookies did not spread excessively, maintained the classic cross cross pattern and baked beautifully at 375 for about 9-10 min. I made half the dough with peanut butter morsels and that was also delicious but the base recipe was really perfect as is!

text:
Great recipe but unless you love super flat cookies, use shortening in place of the butter.   Or use 1/2 c shortening and 1/2 c butter.  (Using butter  instead of shortening in most cookie recipes will lead to flatter cookies).   Flavour is just as fabulous and cookie is more tender than if you add more flour to get a thicker cookie.  And you can still see fork or  crisscross lines in finished product.

text:
The flavor of these were amazing. Surprisingly, they weren't overwhelmingly sweet. I used creamy peanut butter instead of crunchy (because thats what I had in the cupboard!) 
While mine didn't get thin like many other reviews say, they did get hard. I tried turning the heat down for a batch and cooking them for less time on another batch and they all turned out very crisp. 
Still good, but I'm still on the hunt for the perfect soft peanut butter cookie.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made A LOT of cookies. I read that many others were saying the cookies were too thin, so I added a fourth cup more flour, added 1/2 tsp vanilla extract, and rolled each ball in white sugar before placing it on the pan, making a criscross pattern on each ball of dough. Those were my only changes. OH! I used creamy peanut butter and loved these cookies. I even saved about a cup of the batter by rolling it into a log shape and froze it for enjoying later. I figure I can get away with this since the recipe calls for refrigerating the dough anyway - thus the cookies bake the best when they're from cold dough. I plan to let the dough 'thaw' in the fridge overnight before baking the next day. It'll be nice to get my peanut butter cookie fix this easy! Great recipe overall!

text:
I needed to make cookies for the high school soccer team that my husband coaches. Big boys with big appetites. Forgot about peanut allergies but a quick trip to the grocery store will rectify that one. Anyway, after reading all the comments, I did add 1/2 cup flour, split the difference in peanut butter and added an extra 1/3 cup, and also a heaping tsp. vanilla. And leave the dough in the frig over night! As to baking times, I think it depends on the type of baking sheets you're using. Anywhere between 9-10 minutes. I also used a melon baller to keep them small and uniform. They came out perfect and absolutely YUMMY!! The boys should be happy. Especially if they win!

text:
This is a great recipe.  I followed other's advice and increased the amount of peanut butter by 1 cup and added 1 tsp vanilla extract, but did not add any extra flour. I chilled the dough for an hour, made the cookies using a rounded 1/2 tbsp of dough and cooked 10 mins at 350 degrees. The cookies did not come out thin.  So far, I have made 4 dozen cookies and have 2 1/2 rolls of dough in my freezer just from one batch of cookie dough.

Delicious peanuty cookies. I didn't sift the dry ingredients and didn't use vanilla as others suggested. I did use 3/4c more peanut butter . These cookies do harden a bit as they cool so if you want softer cookies, I would suggest following another review and cooking them on 6-7 minutes. Great recipe. text:
The first batch I made, I followed the recipe exactly, but they came out a little dry and crispy. For the rest, I baked them at 325 for 12 minutes, and they had a much more "melt in your mouth" feel than crunch. I'd definitely recommend lowering the temperature and adding a minute or two for extra deliciousness.

text:
Perfect!  I changed the recipe with a swap.  If you don't want as much butter and want these cookies to rise more like chewy puffed up cookies, then swap a stick of butter (1/2 cup) for another half cup of peanut butter.  Either way you do it, it's a classic cookie, and if you are looking to get rid of extra peanut butter in your cabinet, try the swap.

text:
Great recipe! I needed a recipe that used butter since my normal one uses crisco and I want to stay away from it. I did take the advice of other reviewers and added 1/4 cup of extra flour and peanut butter. I also added 1 tsp of vanilla. I left in the fridge for about an hour and a half but I probably could have skipped it. I also replaced about 1/3 stick of butter with coconut oil. I do this for most recipes to help keep moisture and cut out some bad fats. I cooked at 350F for 9-10 min. as others have. The one thing I would have also changed was the amount of salt. They came out way too salty for me. As others stated, a good base recipe.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-06-19T05:21:35.73
helpfulCount:

text:
These are so tasty, and I did not need to change one thing (except I didn't have crunchy peanut butter so I used creamy). I baked them on a silpat and they turned out the perfect thickness and size. The key is to start with COLD dough; refrigerate for at least an hour, if not more, before rolling and baking. To get great fork marks, wet the fork and dip it in sugar.

country:
None
text:
I've made these a couple of times and I usually do half batches, so I use 1 1/2 cups of flour and 3/4 cup of peanut butter and just halve the rest of the ingredients. To prevent the cookies from flattening out while cooking, I only cook one cookie sheet of cookies at a time. The other rack in my oven I move to the top most place and cover it with aluminum foil to disperse the heat in my oven better and so it doesn't blast down on the cookies, and I've found that that usually does the trick. If they are too thick, I'll flatten them out with a spatula and cook them for a minute more. I made two half batches yesterday, the second had dark chocolate chips in it and they are really good.

text:
First off, very simple recipe. Just make sure you cream the butter and sugar long enough. Very important step. 

If you use high quality ingredients and follow these directions exactly, you'll get the best peanut butter cookie I've ever tried. 

The only change I made is I rolled each scoop in sugar before putting on parchment lined cookie sheet. Then flattened with fork. 

I used a #50 scoop and got one short of five dozen. 

Enjoy!

text:
Followed recipe EXACTLY, but only baked them for 8-9 minutes then left on cookie sheet for 1 more minute before moving to a wire rack to cool. They are PERFECT! I don't think they're too thin at all. When pressing with the fork I keep them about 1/2" thick and they bake down to still just over 1/4" after they rest and cool.  We like them slightly chewy so this makes them just perfect for that. No changes to ingredients or measurements is needed. Thanks for the recipe. We enjoyed them (and the cold dough while trying to wait for them to cook).  **The recipe yielded over 50 cookies about 2-3" diameter.**

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2635403.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm overall very pleased with this recipe. 

Standard weights for flour seem to vary from website to website, anywhere from 120 grams per cup to 150 grams, so for this recipe I tried 360 grams of flour (144 per cup), and I added 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla. I baked them without flattening them first, then flattened them slightly while they were cooling. With this amount of flour, the cookies held their shape well and were the perfect texture. Note: It's really important not to over bake these. Also note: I got more like 4 dozen from this recipe instead of the two dozen indicated in the recipe yield.

I may try to reduce the amount of flour next time to see if I can get a  more intense peanut butter flavor without changing the cookie texture.

I took a lot of the reviewers advice and used 1/4 extra flour and 1/4 extra peanut butter. I also sprinkled some sugar on top of the cookies instead of rolling them before baking them.  I also put the dough in the refrigerator for 1 hour prior to baking them.

Although I did like the fact that the cookies weren't greasy as some of the other peanut butter cookie recipes I tried.  I may just have to tweak it to my liking the next time I make these again. 

It was missing something that's for sure .

Cannot say enough good things about these cookies.  I NEVER eat PB cookies b/c I think they are dry and flavorless.  These have totally changed my mind.  Soft, moist, flavorful - heaven in a cookie.

text:
I completely disagree with the reviewers on here who think this recipe needs more flour.  This is my go-to Peanut Butter Cookie recipe, and I follow it  to a "T."  However, whenever I make ANY cookie batter, I always put it in the fridge with cling wrap over the top, for a few hours, or even overnight.  That way the butters get solid again,  and when I scoop it out, it is easy to handle. I This results in a perfect cookie, in my opinion, where the outside edges are somewhat crunchy, while the inside is chewy and the cookie practically melts in your mouth.

userID:
17556489
Display Name:
Mike
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
12
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a basic peanut butter cookie.  Chilling the dough was a setback not major as I am not a cookie baker. I need to read the entire recipe not just scan through.  One to grow on.
The recipe states 24 servings, I made 80 cookies. I guess I would ask how many cookies are in a serving. Like I said I don't bake cookies a whole lot, I looked at the mix and thought wow what big cookies these will be. So used a teaspoon. They spread out and truly bake at 375 for 10 minutes, no more than that. I used parchment paper to bake them on. I took them out of the oven, leave them on the bake tray for a minute or so, otherwise they are mushy and will fall apart.  I mixed them in my kitchen aid, creamed butter and sugars  prior to adding eggs and flour I put the mixer on high for about a minute to aerate the mixture added the balance of ingredients and ran it high once more.  The fork is just for the classic look. They will spread on their own if you choose not to do it.  Don't bake any longer than 10 minutes otherwise they will overbake. Cool and put in airtight containers. I had a few this morning with my coffee. Came out pretty darn good. 
Overall easy cookie and very tasty.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-02-18T09:30:05.027
helpfulCount:

17450652
Display Name:
GadgieCAT13

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe with the changes suggested by a few reviewers (added 1/2C flour and 1/2C peanut butter).  I also left the dough in the fridge for 5 days (I was...busy I guess, ha!).  I ended up with 60 cookies!  What!  I wasn't expecting that many.  I even made the dough balls larger than 1".  Luckily these are really good for peanut butter cookies (I made them for a friend, I don't typically like them).  Since there were plenty of times to put cookies in the oven, I tried different things with each batch:

The first batch was rolled into balls and not pressed down (due to a recommendation from another reviewer).  They came out like flattened balls, which I actually kind of like because they are pretty soft in the middle.  They're cute one-bite cookies.  The second batch was slightly flattened before baking, they came out a little more flat than the first batch.  Two-bite cookies this time, still nice in the middle.  The third batch was pushed down with a fork, traditional style.  They came out looking crackled like typical peanut butter cookies, and the fork marks are sort of visible.  Still nice texture, not as much soft middle as the other batches (obviously).

All batches were taken out of the oven after 10min and immediately moved to a plate to cool.  My advice for avoiding flat, spread-out cookies is to refrigerate the dough for a while.

text:
Husband and I loved these peanut butter cookies!  5 stars!  The first time I made the dough, I followed the printed recipe and we both thought the cookies were delicious; just not"peanut-y" enough.  Second time, I added a teaspoon of vanilla and the extra 1/2 cup of both peanut butter and flour advised by other reviewers, and I thought the dough was a little too dry -- it didn't "roll" into a ball that would hold together well and the dough would break apart when I tried to press the fork tines into the tops.  It was a little better when I pressed the balls into coarse sugar before using the fork, though.  I used my old round ice cream scoop for even-sized cookies.  Baked at 375 degrees for 11 minutes and they came out perfect!  This recipe is a winner!  5+ stars!  Thanks so much for the recipe!

text:
A great recipe but rating a 4 star because I didn't make exactly as recipe stated. However, after reading other reviews and adding 1/4 cup flour, 1/4 cup peanut butter, and 1 tsp. vanilla these came out fantastic. Not sure what would have happened had I not done the  changes. 
The baking time in recipe (10 min) was too long for me.  I use air-bake cookie sheets and usually have to add a few minutes to the time on recipes. At 9 minutes in, I checked and much to my surprise they were already getting brown. About 8-9 mins did it for me.

text:
My favorite peanut butter recipe. Added a teaspoon of vanilla. The only trick to these cookies is creaming the sugar,butter and peanut butter at the same time and then individually add each egg and then adding the vanilla. After creamed slowly adding all mixed dry ingredients and you MUST allow it to sit in the fridge for an hour so the cookies cook without temperament.

text:
I will definitely make this recipe again.  I have been using this recipe for years.  The only thing I change is the oven temp to 350 degrees because my oven seems to run hot and I cook for 7 minutes. Definitely not 10 minutes.  You CANNOT overcook  cookies.  They will taste burnt. I also add 1 teaspoon of lemon juice or I add cream of tarter if I have it.  It makes the cookies crispy around the edges but soft in the center.

text:
I loved these cookies!  My six year old grandson helped with all the measurements and we had no issues. We couldn't be bothered with chilling the dough so we went straight to the shaping part of the recipe. We used a fork dipped in water to press them down a bit on sprayed baking sheets. As a side I should mention my kitchen, even with the oven on, was on the cool side. I also used creamy not crunchy peanut butter. And I made him sift the dry ingredients with a whisk. A little cooking spray on the hands kept the dough from sticking too much on our hands. ;)

text:
O...M...G! These cookies got rave reviews from my guests. I hardly ever leave comments because I usually manage to mess up the recipe but I actually got this one right. Granted, you can not eat more than 2 of these a day without feeling your heart stop... but man are they worth it! The only think I did differently (unintentionally) was use creamy PB instead of crunchy. Can't wait to see how they taste with the crunchy. I would suggest adjust the cooking times and temps based on what you know of your oven. No 2 ovens are the same. For example, I had to bake mine on tin foil at 350 for 7 min. exactly. At 6 they're under cooked, at 8 or more they're burnt.

text:
I have baked these to the recipe and they were fantastic. I like to experiment so for softer cookies I took half the white sugar away and replaced it with an equal amount of brown sugar. They were great. My next experiment was crispy cookies, so I  reversed the sugar ratio. These were fantastic also. It's a personal preference, but the original recipe is a great start. I use smooth organic pb and add 1 cup of chopped peanuts. I top each cookie with half a pecan. Delish! V

text:
My husband has a sweet tooth that I am trying to curve by baking fresh for him instead of store bought. At least I know what is in the sweets he is eating, all natural and no additives.  He is also a very finicky cookie fan.  I had to do a lot of research before I found this recipe.  The last one I tried didn't even taste like peanut butter.  He gave this recipe two thumbs up!  
I didn't change anything about the recipe. I used an all natural organic peanut butter and organic sugar.  Using a stand mixer is a must.  I left the dough in the fridge all afternoon while we were out.  Then I used a cookie scoop and handled the dough as little as possible so that they were still cold and hard when they went into the oven.  They came out looking exactly like the photo and tasted very peanuty!  Thank you for sharing!!

text:
These are the perfect peanut butter cookies, with just a couple of tweaks.  I used salted butter, 1 1/2 c brown sugar, 1/2 c white sugar, and added 1 tsp vanilla to the mixture when I creamed it.  I also doubled the peanut butter.  I only used 1/4 tsp of salt, and baked the cookies for 8 minutes at about 360.  They were soft and thick -- didn't spread at all.  These are everybody's favorite peanut butter cookies!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made gluten-free peanut butter cookies with this recipe, simply by substituting 2 cups of Krusteaz all-purpose gluten-free flour plus 1/2 cup coconut flour in place of the standard all-purpose flour called for in the recipe. (I'm sure you could just use 2 1/2 cups of the gluten-free flour and skip the coconut flour, but I had some coconut flour that I wanted to use.) I also used regular peanut butter instead of crunchy because that's what I had on hand. I let the dough get completely chilled before rolling it into balls, and I made mine slightly bigger than 1-inch ball.  They turned out really well and I got huge compliments from the gluten-free folks when I shared these at a gathering. (I'm not gluten-free but I like to experiment.)

userID:

Display Name:
Jill Maxfield
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the cookies exactly as written because most of the reviews are based on changes to the recipe.    Because of the spreading mentioned by many reviewers I made sure to chill the dough for an hour and did not overmix.  I shaped the dough into balls about the size of a ping pong ball and very lightly pressed them in a criss cross pattern with a moistened fork making sure not to flatten too much.  At this point they were about 1/2-3/4" thick.  I baked for 10 minutes, or until just barely brown on the edges.  The cookies did spread to about 3" in diameter, and were about 1/4" thick when cooled.   They are a soft/chewy cookie, not crisp.  I would prefer a crisper cookie, more like shortbread, which is why I only gave the recipe 4 stars.

I halved the recipe and used 1/2 cup zero calorie sweetener (sucrolose/splenda) and then added 1 cup peanut butter chips! I also skipped the refrigerator part.. I dissolved the baking soda in 1 teaspoon hot water and added the baking soda to the dough and salt before the flour. The dough was fluffy and perfect! They turned out fantastic but in part due to the peanut butter chips because I left out white sugar and used the substitute.
I also used 1 cup peanut butter instead of 1/2 since I halved the recipe it only called for 1/2 cup.  Try it!

text:
These were the best peanut butter cookies I have ever made! I added 1/4 cup more flour to make them more fluffy and chewy as the first time they were too crispy and flat for my taste. I also added 1/2 cup more crunchy peanut butter for some extra flavor! The standard 1 cup is good as well, though, for a delicate, light flavor. I also added 1 teaspoon of vanilla and all of this balanced perfectly. Additionally I did not cross the cookies with a fork because I wanted them to be as full and fluffy as possible. Making again!

text:
I've made PLENTY of PB cookies in my many years of baking...& this recipe is my above & beyond Favorite one!!  You just HAVE TO take them out of the oven  when they're just starting to get a bit crispy on the edges.  They WILL be soft, but, just leave them on the cookie sheet for a few minutes before trying to lift them (I use a spatula, like I use for my pancake flipping, either the small one or my larger one, depending on the size of the cookie I make.)   These are my husband's absolute favorite cookie... So, I make them @ LEAST once or twice a month!!! (Sometimes to fancy them up a bit...or, if I feel like it), I'll dip half of each cookie in some melted chocolate chips... either dark or white ones.... Yummy!

userID:
14223812
Display Name:
Susanna Wheat
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
28
favoritesCount:
42
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took another reviewer's suggestion and increased the peanut butter to 1 1/2 cups, added an additional 1/4 cup flour, and baked at 350 degrees for 9-10 minutes; Refrigerated overnight; rolled into balls and had my daughter (age 3.5) roll the balls in sugar and press them with a fork (she did remarkably well btw).  Don't roll/sugar/press too many minutes before cooking, otherwise the sugar you roll will start to get too wet and won't give you that sugary taste after cooking.  I was impressed how they turned out, just a little crispy on the outside but soft and chewy on the inside.  To make sure you don't over cook them (or any cookie really) - the top of the cookie will go from wet looking to "dry".  I used to look for the golden sides, but honestly, this technique has baked many batches of cookies with that awesome taste of soft Otis store bought type cookies.

userID:

Display Name:
JOLARA
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/44407.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were delicious cookies! I see a lot of people having issues with their cookies being too flat. Try using Bakers Flour in lieu of All Purpose (Yes, still include the additional leavening ingredients.) Outside of a different flour, I added an additional  1/2 C of both flour and peanut butter and a bag of mini Reese's bits. I spread the dough out into a 9x13 baking dish, covered with cellophane and let sit in the fridge for about 3 hrs.  Rolled into 1" balls and lightly cross crossed with a fork dipped in granulated sugar. In our oven, we baked 1 dozen at a time for 12 min and they came out perfect! They only spread just a tad so we got a 1/2" thick cookie that is a little crispy outer shell and a soft & chewy center. Will definitely use this recipe again.

I was looking for a go-to peanut butter cookie recipe. Following the recipes exactly, I made a batch of these and Joey's Peanut Butter cookies, also on All Recipes, and took them to work. Of the 30 people who participated in my taste test, they came out at a tie.  But by the end of the day though, the Joey's were breaking apart while this Classic Peanut Butter Cookie was holding its shape in the zip lock.  As they were tied for taste, this is now my go-to peanut butter cookie because it held up better for transporting.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As did other reviewers, I added a half cup more pb and a quarter cup more flour. I didn't have an hour to chill so I stuck the dough in the freezer and mixed it up a couple times to cool quicker. I also didn't have unsalted butter so I added less salt and I added a touch of vanilla. I dipped the tops of the "balls" in sugar before I pressed them with the fork. I ended up cooking them about 12.5 minutes and kept an eye on them in 30 second intervals to ensure they were just starting to get a hint of color but I don't think I will even do that next time. I think mine could have been taken out at 11 minutes, maybe 11.5 if you want to get that technical. No issues with flat cookies.

text:
This recipe is amazing as is. I was a pb cookie virgin, but I made this using typical cookie approach: cream fat/sugars/eggs for 5-10 minutes to help make fluffy cookies. I sifted my flour, didn't even bother refrigerating the dough, and used am ice cream scooper to make balls (so that the dough was handled very minimally), made slight fork marks and baked 10-11 minutes on a silpat. Hole

text:
Made these following some of the suggestions above.  Increased peanut butter and flour both by 1/4 cup, and added 2 teas vanilla to wet ingredients. Rolled balls in vanilla sugar, flattened and used fork to do criss-cross pattern. Baked at 350 for 10-11 minutes, came out very nice.  Slighlty crispy and chewy.  Will make again. (Also added dark chocolate chips to 1/2 of the dough - they turend out really good!)

country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe except I used creamy peanut butter instead of crunchy (which I didn't have on hand).  I think that the people who feel a need to add more peanut butter might not be using crunchy.  With the actual pieces of peanut in the cookie, it would enhance the peanut flavor.  I'll use crunchy next time.  I chilled the dough for an hour and the cookies spread the perfect amount.  Not flat at all, perfectly round, no need to add more flour.

text:
I liked this recipe but knew that a lot of people were experiencing overly thin cookies. To help with this I used half shortening and half butter, being sure the butter wasn't overly soft. I also used half a cup extra peanut butter and a tablespoon of vanilla extract to improve the flavor. The fork pattern was a nice touch and as long as you don't flatten them too much it'll be fine, keep in mind they are meant to spread a bit in the oven

text:
Very good--a little different in texture, since when my children were growing up, I made them probably the size estimated here.  I added the extra flour and peanut butter as others mentioned here, plus the teaspoon of vanilla.  The flavor would be richer with the butter; however, since I had none, I used 1/2 cup cube margarine plus 1/2 cup shortening.  Since everyone seems to like cookies larger these days, that's what I did, ending up with about 3 dozen.  Just right at 375 degrees at 9 minutes.  I tried some at 350 degrees earlier after preheating, but they were too pale.

userID:
15024785
Display Name:
Hailey
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
8
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are to die for. They are the perfect amount of peanut butter and all of the other ingredients made the cookies taste much better than the classic recipes that you find on the back of the peanut butter container. I wanted to go straight into the baking without seeing any comments so that I could give this a pure rating. Stay tuned if you would like to hear my recommendations.                                                                                                                        I made a large mistake during the first direction. While I was combining the butter, peanut butter and sugars, I left the stand mixer for a minute. 1 MINUTE! In that minute the butter whipped. I then returned to a very light mixture. If this happens to you DON'T WORRY. I actually had none of the problems that anyone else had. I also didn't have enough flour and only put in 2 1/4 cup flour but once again it did not mess up my cookies. Once I was done making the dough, I put it in the fridge. I went shopping and lost track of time which led me to leaving the dough in the fridge for 2 and a half hours but that once again did not mess up my cookies. The dough was a perfect consistency and didn't grip the fork so I did not have to use any sugar to keep it from sticking. Once cooked the cookies return to peanut butter colour. I highly recommend this and don't worry if your mixture is more white than it was in the video. It may even turn out better then the regular recipe.

text:
This is the best peanut butter cookie I've ever had. I did follow some of the other folks suggestions and used 1 1/2 cups peanut butter, and 2 2/3 cups flour instead of the measurements used in the recipe. I chilled the dough for about 20 hours in the fridge. I also rolled the dough balls in sugar, and baked them for 11 minutes at 350 degrees in my toaster oven. They turned out amazing. Just check out the pictures of the final product!

Display Name:
gyerkes76
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really like this recipe.  I rolled my dough larger than I should have but I like a larger cookie.  No big deal, but the trade off is you will lose most of the fork marks.  The taste is wonderful, not too sweet.  I chose to use salted butter (since I didn't have unsalted on hand) and ditched the salt addition listed.  I'm not sure why there are so many negative reviews.  If the batter looks too loose or you know your oven tends to run hot, use your best judgment!  Add a little flour or turn your oven down; my oven runs very hot so I turned it down to 360 degrees and had no burning issues.  I highly recommend this recipe, just remember to keep your dough chilled right up until you put in the oven!  If you have some lag time between shaping and baking or more dough to prepare while waiting for a free cookie sheet, pop the dough/prepped unbaked cookies back in the fridge until the pan is ready to go into the oven.  Good luck!!

text:
I just finished making these cookies and they are wonderful. My son requested peanut butter cookies with chocolate chips in them. I did use creamy pb, because that is all I had. After reading some of the comments, I increased the flour and the peanut butter. I did not have any trouble with rolling the dough. The chocolate chips I used were frozen, and I did refrigerate the dough with the chips inside for almost an hour. Maybe because the chips were right from the freezer into the dough, that might have helped. I baked them at 350 for about 10 minutes.  I had no trouble with them flattening out whatsoever. Actually, mine did not flatten hardly at all.  They came out more like a cake-like cookie - which I like.  My son loves them and so do I.
Thank you for the original post, and for all the comments/suggestions!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these cookies today. I think they are the best peanut butter cookies I've ever made. I made some adaptations based on some of the other reviews, but I also live at 7800 feet, so I needed to adjust for high altitude. To adjust for high altitude, I only used 3/4 cup butter and I cut back to 1 tsp baking soda and 1/2 tsp baking powder. In deference to the review recommendations, which were all great, I also added 1/2 cup extra peanut butter, 1/2 cup extra flour and 1 tsp vanilla. I love chocolate chips in my peanut butter cookies, so I added 1 cup+ mini chocolate chips. I don't like flat, crispy cookies, so I always refrigerate dough for 2-3 hours before baking and keep the dough in the fridge in between baking sheets of cookies. I think they come out better. This was a great recipe to start, the recommendations from the reviewers were spot on. I will make these again.

THIS IS PERFECT! The cookies came out as a perfect and the texture was heavenly. I didn't have crunchy peanut butter, so I had to do creamy. We added some chocolate chips and it was FABULOUS. The cookies spread out more than I had planned, so next time I'll add a bit more flour. Perhaps 1/3 a cup. I added some more vanilla extract,and they were the bomb! Do want to hear a good serving tip? Mash 4 cookies in a 1/4 cup of milk and it tastes like ice cream and cookies that you can get at Chile's. That sounds crazy right? But it was awesome. We made about 25 cookies and in a family of 4, they were devoured without leftovers. My bro asked me if we could make this instead of regular cookies, and A LOT MORE OFTEN. Well I'l tell you this. I agree.

text:
So I use this recipe as a base and tweaked it for what I had in the cupboard. 
I used

1 cup powered sugar
2 1/2  cups whole wheat pastry flower
A good sized glob honey
a big big spoonful maple sugar
1 1/2 sticks butter
1 cup creamy peanut butter
One big giant spoonful trader Joe's Cookie &Coco swirl spread
2 eggs
Salt, baking soda, baking powder the same as recipe


Mixed and baked the same as recipe, topped with trader Joe's cinnamon sugar ( in the grinder)

Turned out yum! 
Thanks !

text:
Halloween 2014 I took my 6 children trick or treating. When we got to the house I realized how much candy we had gotten :-( it didnt look so good....we had so much candy we filled 2 medium size duffle bags. I knew this wasnt right I searched for places to donate candy to, when the greatest ideal came to me.....I can use the chocolate to make cookies. I found this recipe and BOY I'm glad I did!  I did add the 1/4 flour and extra peanut butter. I crushed up all the chocolate and poured it in after I shifted my dry ingredients.  Scared not knowing what the cookies would taste like considering it was all types of chocolate candy (Reeses,  Hersey,  cookie and cream hershey, paydays, snickers, kitkats, 3 musketeers,  babe Ruths, m&ms etc) I just wasn't sure if it would come out right.  The cookies were wonderful!  They came out HUGE and soft! !! My children loved them and I got rid of a half of bag of candy :-). Note I have an Electric stove so I baked on 350 for 9-10 mins. 


Oh yeah the next day I uses the left over batter and brewers yeast and fennel seed to the batch and made lactation cookies and they turned out great! Im really happy I found this recipe.

This was a great recipe and the cookies turned out awesome!  I gave some to friends and they said that they were the best peanut butter cookies they have had in a long time.  Prior to baking the cookies, I read some reviews and decided to add  cup more of peanut butter and  more of flour so the cookies turned out soft and chewy.  I also used creamy peanut butter instead of crunchy.  I baked the cookies for 8 minutes and let them cool on a plate (not wire rack).  I would recommend this recipe to any peanut butter cookie lover!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I rated this recipe 5 stars and I think that is due mostly to all the fantastic comments before me. I read the comments and  lot of comments discussed runny consistency so I made some tweaks. First of all, I made this with creamy peanut butter and that was only due to the fact that we had creamy in the house. Secondly, I added 1/2 each of flour and peanut butter as many comments suggested. Thirdly, I put the cookie dough in the fridge for 24 hours to firm up better for baking. Finally, I added in some chopped Reese's cups and white chocolate chips. I baked my cookies at 350 but I can not tell you for how long since I don't like to follow timers but remove them when they are done. My first batch came out looking not real runny but still a little smaller than I would like so with the second batch I made bigger balls of cookie dough and Volia! the perfect cookie. It tastes fantastic but I would recommend using more flour and peanut butter and letting the dough sit in your fridge for a while before you cook it so you don't waste all the ingredients due to a runny cookie.

text:
These were so yummy! Wanted cookies as a late night snack and peanut butter was the only thing I had. I didn't have brown sugar so I just added the white sugar plus 1/4, nor did I have baking butter, so was surprised how good these still came out. I made them with freshly ground peanut butter where you grind it up at the store. My family ate them all up in two days. I did follow,DENIELLE2's advise on adding 1/4 more flour and 1/4 more peanut butter. Which made them more softer/chewier. I was going to do JENNIFERC77's advise but didn't have that much peanut butter. I'm going to make these my go to peanut butter cookies.

text:
This recipe is delicious, and I was pleasantly surprised. I kept the recipe just about the same except for adding a 1/2 cup of flour as others suggested, and 1/4 cup of peanut butter. I also added 1 tbsp of cornstarch to dough for taste. The only difficult part of making the cookies was stirring the flour mixture with the peanut butter mixture. I stirred and stirred at least 10 minutes!!! Other than that, the cookies came out soft and tasty, with a subtle peanut butter flavor. I cooked these cookies right at 10 minutes. I was able to make just shy of 3 dozen. Yum!

text:
Thank you Shirley for a surely delicious cookie.

I made the recipe EXACTLY and cookies were very good.  The dough MUST BE REFRIGERATED for at least the recommended time.  This will stop the cookie from spreading while baking.  Also, because it is butter based, make sure you bake them on a parchment paper lined cookie sheet. :-)

The TWEAKED RECIPE -increased the peanut butter and flour by 1/2 cup each and added 1 teaspoon of vanilla.  OH YEAH, BABY!  YUMMY!  Yet another suggestion, add some finely chopped up dates, maraschino cherries and walnuts or peanuts. Thank People for your suggestions.

text:
These cookies were really good.  Took them to where I volunteer and the girls raved about them and they all disappeared.  They looked fantastic and depending on your preference you could have crunchy or soft.  I baked soft ones for 11 minutes and crispy 13 min.  The only change I will make next time is add a little more peanut butter.  I don't know if because I used natural peanut butter (without hydrogenated oils) if this made it taste less peanut like)  I like more peanut butter taste.  I would not add vanilla to this recipe as it would distract from the flavor you are trying to acquire.  I also used a melon baller to make sure all cookies about same size.  Then I rolled them in some sugar and when on cookie sheet I flatten slightly with fork in crisscross manner.  Wish I had taken a picture but they were gone before I got a chance.

text:
Very good cookies.  I didn't have crunchy PB, so I used creamy.  I also didn't have unsalted butter so I used salted and just left out the salt called for in the recipe.  I've made PB cookies before and I know what happens when you flatten the cookie for the imprint so I didn't flatten the cookie, just pressed the fork lightly into the dough. Mine came out looking just like the picture.  Will absolutely keep the recipe as a starter and add my own twists on it.  Thanks Shirley.

I made this recipe and it was wonderful. The cookies came out soft and a bit crisp. The taste was rather bland, so I did add a little bit of peanut butter. I am not a fan of peanut butter cookies, but they were just right. I don't like for my peanut butter cookies to be too overbearing with peanut butter taste. I do like my peanut butter cookies a bit more crisp. So I just added another 1 to 2 minutes. This was a great recipe! I loved them and my husband loved them as well. I may have had to adjust the ingredients, but since I don't like my peanut butter cookies overbearing, this recipe was delicious and deserved 5 golden stars!

None
text:
These cookies taste just heavenly! They came out the same way as on the picture, taste and texture perfect. For those who like fluffier cookies, substitute butter with shortening. On a well-known brand website (wink): "Shortening doesn't contain water, so if you want to get the same results as you get with butter or margarine, adjust the water according to the chart below. (A shortening cookie with no extra water added is higher and lighter, while a butter cookie is flatter and crispier.)" Since I didn't have enough butter handy, I used same amount of golden shortening, and whisked in 2 TBS of water in it. If you like your cookie lighter and higher, don't had the water. Yummy!

Ok so I had high hopes for this recipe and I followed the recommendations of the other reviewers and added an additional cup of flour, a half cup of peanut butter and the teaspoon of vanilla. Put the dough in the frig for an hour and then rolled them into balls and baked them for the ten minutes. They look nice but taste bad in my book, I can harderly tastes the peanut butter and they are super fragile. I am making another batch right now with 2 cups of the peanut butter and then sprinkling sugar on top. I also made them smaller in the hopes that they won't fall apart... Hopefully these come out decent.

text:
Like several others, I added 1/4 cup each of peanut butter and flour as well as 1 tsp of vanilla.  I also added half a bag of peanut butter chips.  I used a scooper to ensure they bake evenly then rolled them in white sugar.  Instead of the "fork design" on the cookie, I pressed them down slightly with the back of a spoon and baked them for 9 minutes @ 350 degrees.  The cookies are AWESOME!!!  They reminded me of Panera's Peanut Butter Dream cookie.  

I will DEFINITELY be making these again.  Next time I'll add more peanut butter chips and a bit less butter.  The cookies were a tad greasy, but still AWESOME!

text:
These are awesome, the BEST Peanut Butter Cookies Ever!  I did follow the other posts and added an extra 1/2 cup of flour and an extra 1/2 cup of Kraft Smooth Peanut Butter along with the recommended vanilla extract.  I did let the mixture cool in the refrigerator for an hour as well as between batches.  I also rolled the balls in sugar before pressing with a fork to make the criss-cross effect.  I baked for 10 minutes on 350.  I did watch them closely.  YUMMY!!!  Will definitely make these again.  Vegas155

text:
OK, I've made this recipe before and followed it exactly, and for me, the cookies were great. However, I wanted PB cookies today and had no butter Sub'd in shortening, plus 3T water, and also added a bit of extra flour after reading reviews. That's probably great when you use butter, but shortening is OMG NOOOO!!! My dough was crumbly as heck, so I added some more PB, some more water, and a bit of veg oil until it was wet enough to at least make a ball. It's still really dry, and the cookies I baked (only one batch so far) are really pale. I haven't tasted them yet, but I envision a crumbly mess! Probably make this recipe with butter :)

text:
Wow.  Chewy, peanut buttery, and oh so addictive!  My grandmother-in-law made this recipe, and she complained that the cookies flattened during cooking, but I didn't really care; they were still delicious.  No complaints whatsoever here!  EDIT:  I made this recipe again last night and changed it up a little to fix the complaints Grandma had.  For one, I added a little extra peanut butter and flour as the reviewers suggested.  For two, I refrigerated thoroughly--more like three hours, and put the dough in the refrigerator between batches in the oven.  Three, I made smaller cookies--three dozen out of a half batch.  Mine turned out very differently--they didn't flatten much, and they were crisp on the outside, chewy on the inside.  Perfect!

Display Name:
Miss Meara

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the recipe as directed - with three changes.  I didn't have unsalted peanut butter, so I used regular creamy peanut butter and omitted the salt.  I also added a cup of unsalted dry-roasted peanuts.  The cookies are delicious - but a little mild in the peanut butter taste.  I will add more peanut butter the next time I make them (and keep the peanuts - they add a lovely texture).  Also, it's very easy to over-cook these.  After they were pressed on the pan, I placed it in the fridge for 15 mins.  I then cooked them at 350 for 6 minutes.  (My oven runs hot.)  They were chewy and crispy on just they outermost edges.  Don't wait for them to brown - you'll end up with a very hard and dry cookie. (The dogs loved those hard ones though.)  Thank you for the recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews, I added 1/2 cup extra AP flour and maybe 1/4 cup extra peanut butter, and a smidge of vanilla. I also substituted in a cup of whole wheat flour, trying to trick myself into thinking these would be a healthy snack ;)  Fanatstic cookies! Perfect texture, beautiful light color, nice form and thickness, and, of course, delicious! Folks...if any of your cookie recipies are spreading too thin, remember 1. use softened but not warm butter (never get it goopy in a microwave!) 2. don't over-mix the butter & sugar, just barely cream them together with a lower speed until evenly mixed, 3. don't spray your cookie pans, use parchment paper or tin foil and 4. refrigerate the dough before baking. Works every time!

text:
Final result was awesome!! I increased the flour by 1/2 cup as suggested as for the peanut butter I used the 1 cup of crunchy peanut butter plus 2 TBS. Creamy peanut butter and 2 TBS. All natural p.b. I also didn't have butter on hand  and for some reason I had lard( oh yeah I used it to make tamales lol!)so I subbed the lard for the butter. I accedently put 1 tsp of salt instead of 1/2 tsp.(which I would do again I love the salty sweet thing with these cookies)  I also had to add 2 tbs. Cold water ( as the dough was a bit dry and crumbled when I tried to form my balls) I made large cookies 2 oz balls I dipped them in sugar and flattened with a fork I baked at 350 for 11 mins on top rack. Cooled them on a wire rack for 5 mins . These turned out better than I ever could have imagined. My mistakes and not having the right ingredients turned into a blessing from Jesus Christ himself. The rich and intense peanut flavor light and crisp with a soft chewy center. This is by far the best peanut butter cookie I have ever placed in my mouth better than any bakery or gourmet cookie shop. It was complete extasy from the moment it touched my tongue. I will definatley make this again exactly the same way!!

text:
Wow, these are better than anything you can buy at a bakery. I use creamy peanut butter, and added peanut butter chips for fun. The first time I made them, I had no eggs, so I substituted a flax egg (3 TBS ground flaxseed and 1 TBS water mixed). They stayed soft and chewy for the whole week. I've kept with the flax because I think maybe it helped keep them soft--I could be wrong. Super addictive, so watch out. I find that chilling the dough for an hour and using a cookie baller worked really well. It made them into fluffy 3-bite balls. I don't press them down with a fork. I'm about to make batch number 5 today to give as a welcome gift to our new neighbors--they're perfect.

I often make cookies for the small office where I work.  There are only 8 of us.  Usually cookies take a few days to disappear.  These were gone by 3:00pm the day I put them out. 

They are light, crispy and crunchy with a perfect peanut flavor.  There's nothing cakey or too dry about this cookie.  I added chocolate chips because who doesn't love chocolate and peanut butter? This recipe is by far the best Peanut Butter Cookie recipe I've come across.
Update 10/23/2018 - it's still the best Peanut Butter Cookie recipe I've ever found.  This is one cookie that people request over and over again.

text:
OH MY GOODNESS! It's really great!
Pros: It's really good and it lives up to its name. The peanuts can really be tasted and the texture's good. The servings really big too! :D
Cons: I am a beginner too so it was a bit hard using the mixer, I think I over mixed it making it dry. I added another egg because my eggs were a bit small and half a glass of water because it was a bit dry. You also have to bake it 2-3 times before you get the hang of it, especially timing the cookies when their perfect. You need practice or experience to really get it perfect the first time but it's not impossible.

I followed other comments, so I added 1/2 cup of flour and 1/2 cup of peanut butter. Fantastic.

Thank you for sharing the recipe! :D

userID:
12031786
Display Name:
Loretta
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just finished making these cookies for a church event I am going to.  The cookies were perfect and so Delish!  

I used smooth almond butter because I wanted to use up what I had in the pantry, and it tastes just as good as peanut butter.  I used about  1&1/4 cup of the almond butter.  I used 3 eggs and added 1/2 cup more flour & the consistancy was perfect.  I used a stainless steel mixing bowl and put the dough in the freezer for about 15 minutes and the dough was easy to handle. I have a cookie scoop (like a small ice cream scoop)and the cookies are uniform in size that way, not to mention faster and easier to scoop up. I always dip my fork in flour before I make the criss cross design, then redip it for the next cookie. The fork never sticks to the cookies that way. 
 
I have two large cookie sheets and only bake one sheet at a time.  I line the sheets with heavy foil, dull side up, and let the cookies cool completely on the foil (after I slide it, cookies and all, off the pan) then I can reuse the cookie sheet. 12 minutes in my oven was just right. This recipe yielded 4 dozen & 8 cookies, about 3 & 1/4 inches across.

I had some chocolate kisses in the pantry so I unwrapped them while the cookies baked and when they came out of the oven I put a kiss in the middle of each hot cookie and pressed down a bit.  They melted just at the bottom, enough to hold them in the center of the cookie after they cooled.  

I will make these again with my grandchildren next week!

text:
So good! I love that everyone tweaks these recipes to make them their own. Here are my tweaks: First of all, I used all ORGANIC ingredients, that makes all the difference in the world. I added 1/2 tspn of vanilla extract, added butterscotch chips, used salted butter, 1 tspn of salt instead of a 1/2, added a dash of nutmeg, and substituted pure honey & real maple syrup for the white sugar. I almost didn't finish these cookies because I couldn't stop eating the batter! If I could name my version of this recipe, I would call it Salted-Honey Peanut Butter Cookies. :)

text:
These cookies are delicious!

I took the advice of other reviewers and increased the peanut butter.  I was "loose" with that and added approximately 1/2 c. more.  I also added a full (exact) 1/2 c. of flour knowing I liked a dryer outside texture for my cookie.  

I used natural peanut butter (the kind you stir because the oil separates); a 50/50 mix of white and wheat flour; salted butter since I had no unsalted in the house (I omitted adding any additional salt to offset its content); and powdered egg mix (placing the water in the moist batter and the powder in with the flour).

The result was a beautiful cookie in appearance, texture and taste.

text:
I followed this recipe exactly and it came out perfect!  They came out crunchy outside and moist inside......needless to say PERFECT! I also made a batch with chocolate chips that were just as delicious. If you have problems with this recipe it may be your baking soda or that you are handling the dough for fortoo longand letting it get soft in your hands. Try putting them back in the fridge for bout 10 minutes once you have them rolled o to your cookie sheets, then straight to the oven from there!

userID:
8510301
Display Name:
bitterquill
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
102
favoritesCount:
10
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually use creamy peanut butter rather than crunchy, and I generally add an extra 1/2 cup for a stronger peanut butter flavor. I also chill the dough for at least three hours, and I take just enough dough out of the fridge to shape *one* batch before it goes in the oven, so the remaining dough never gets too warm and soft (which happens very quickly, especially after you shape it with warm hands); I take the next bit of dough out of the fridge for shaping about two minutes before the first comes out of the oven. I prefer a chewier cookie, so I cook mine for 13-14 minutes at 300 F, and allow them to cool for several minutes on the cookie sheet before transferring them to a wooden cutting board (otherwise they are too soft). Another reviewer mentioned not to flatten them with a fork, and that they will seem underdone when you remove them from the oven. I *always* flatten them with a fork just a little bit, but they do spread a little so don't go crazy with it; I usually do only eight per cookie sheet if I'm using my smaller pan, just to be sure they don't touch, but I have never had an issue with excessive spread. I do agree that you will likely think they are underdone when you take them out. They will flatten, harden and even darken just a tiny bit as they cool. This recipe has a large yield so you can always do a couple of test cookies to get the timing perfect for your oven. :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-01-15T11:16:43.547
helpfulCount:
0

Absolutely delicious! I made those yesterday (only 1 dozen) and they came out perfectly chewy, sweet and peanut buttery. Just note that if you use oil they'll need to set for a couple of hours or overnight in an open jar to get the proper texture and aroma. Five stars without hesitation!
